knowledge_graph.title: Organizational ethics
knowledge_graph.description: Organizational ethics is the ethics of an organization, and it is how an organization responds to an internal or external stimulus. Organizational ethics is interdependent with the organizational culture.

related_questions.question: What do you mean by ethical organization?
related_questions.snippet: Organizational ethics – also known as business ethics – are the values, principles, and standards that guide the individual and group behavior of the people in an organization. Business ethics are set up to steer and manage activities and business situations to proactively avoid harmful behavior.
related_questions.title: Organizational Ethics: An Actionable Guide for HR - AIHR

related_questions.question: What is an example of an ethical organization?
related_questions.snippet: Patagonia, The Body Shop, and Ben & Jerry's stories remind us that ethical business is not just about rules and regulations. It's about living a company's values every day, making decisions with integrity, and treating all stakeholders with respect.
related_questions.title: Ethical Business Examples That Make A Difference - Virtuzone

related_questions.question: What defines an ethical company?
related_questions.snippet: An ethical company is a company that treats people well. Companies can sometimes be too focused on making money and end up hurting people along the way. However, an ethical company will try to minimize the negative impact that they have on people and maximize the good that they do while they operate.
